page.title: xian
page.text: {{also|xī'àn|Xian|xián|xiàn|xiān|xiǎn|Xi'an|Xī'ān|xī'ān}} ==English== ===Etymology 1=== From the [[pinyin]] romanization of {{bor|en|cmn|-}} {{zh-m|縣}}. {{wikipedia|County (China)|Counties in China}} ====Alternative forms==== * {{alter|en|hsien||archaic}} ====Noun==== {{en-noun}} # {{lb|en|China}} An [[administrative]] [[subdivision]] of [[imperial]], [[republican]], and [[communist]] [[China]] [[roughly]] [[equivalent]] to [[county|counties]], [[now]] [[distinguish]]ed from the [[more]] [[urban]] "[[district]]s" ([[qu]]). #: {{syn|en|county}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=1987 |last=Rawson |first=Jessica |authorlink=Jessica Rawson |chapter=The Eastern Zhou Period |title=Chinese Bronzes: Art and Ritual |url=https://archive.org/details/chinesebronzesar00raws/ |publisher={{w|British Museum Publications}} |ISBN=0-7141-1439-1 |OCLC=1183919119 |page=47 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/chinesebronzesar00raws/page/47/ |text=Tight and dense motifs occur on bronzes excavated in 1923 from a tomb at Lijialou at Xinzheng<!--新鄭--> '''Xian''' in southern Henan attributed to the small state of Zheng.}} =====Derived terms===== * {{l|en|Gui Xian}} ===Etymology 2=== An alternative capitalization of [[Xian]]. ====Noun==== {{en-noun}} # {{lb|en|sometimes|_|pejorative|_|or|_|offensive}} {{alt form|en|Xian|nodot=a}}: [[Christian]]. ====Adjective==== {{en-adj|-}} # {{lb|en|sometimes|_|pejorative|_|or|_|offensive}} {{alt form|en|Xian|nodot=a}}: [[Christian]]. #* {{quote-book |en |year=1993 |title=The Selected Letters of Mary Moody Emerson |first=Mary Moody |last=Emerson |authorlink=Mary Moody Emerson |editor=Simmons, Nancy Craig |publisher=University of Georgia Press |location=Athens |page=242 |pageurl=http://books.google.com/books?id=GbviVhvwUpoC&pg=PA242&dq=xian |passage=But what an epoch in the xian world—what a time for a xian Orator to make a deep & eternal impression on socity{{SIC}}. }} ====References==== * [http://www.infidels.org/library/modern/mathew/arguments.html#xian What does 'xian' mean?] ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=ainx|Axin|Naxi|axin}} [[Category:en:Christianity]] ---- ==Mandarin== ===Romanization=== {{cmn-pinyin|notr=1}} # {{nonstandard spelling of|cmn|sc=Latn|xiān}} # {{nonstandard spelling of|cmn|sc=Latn|xián}} # {{nonstandard spelling of|cmn|sc=Latn|xiǎn}} # {{nonstandard spelling of|cmn|sc=Latn|xiàn}} ====Usage notes==== * {{cmn-toneless-note}}

page.text: {{also|Xīchéng}} ==English== {{wikipedia}} {{commonscat|Xicheng District}} ===Alternative forms=== * {{q|from [[Wade–Giles]]}} {{l|en|Hsi-ch'eng}} ===Etymology=== From the {{bor|en|cmn-pinyin|-}} [[romanization]] of {{uder|en|cmn|-}} Chinese {{zh-l|西城|lit=[[west]] [[city]]}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|en|/ʃiːˈt͡ʃʌŋ/}} ===Proper noun=== {{head|en|proper noun}} # {{place|en|district|in [[downtown]]|city/Beijing|c/China|comprising the sections immediately [[west]] of the [[Forbidden City]]}}. #* {{quote-book |en |year=1983 |author=Clifton W. Pannell |author2=Laurence J. C. Ma |title=China: The Geography of Development and Modernization |url=https://archive.org/details/chinageographyof0000pann/ |publisher=V. H. Winston & Sons |ISBN=0-470-27377-1 |page=85 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/chinageographyof0000pann/page/85/ |text=The city of Peking has 85 neighborhoods, each with more than 50,000 residents (Luo, 1980). The Fengsheng Neighborhood in the '''Xicheng''' District of Peking, for example, has 14,136 families and 52,978 persons.}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=1989 |author=Yi Mu; Mark V. Thompson |title=Crisis at Tiananmen: Reform and Reality in Modern China |url=https://archive.org/details/crisisattiananme00yimu/ |location=[[San Francisco]] |publisher={{w|China Books}} |ISBN=0-8351-2290-5 |LCCN=89-81313 |OCLC=499120267 |page=229 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/crisisattiananme00yimu/page/229/ |text=In Xixingsheng lane of the '''Xicheng''' District, more than 20 armed policemen were beaten up by mobs; some were badly injured, and the others’ whereabouts are unknown.}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=2000 |last=Brown |first=J. D. |title=Beijing |series={{w|Frommer's}} |url=https://archive.org/details/frommersbeijing00brow/ |location=[[Foster City]], CA |publisher={{w|IDG Books}} |ISBN=0-02-862960-4 |ISSN=1520-5568 |OCLC=43481306 |OL=7268947M |page=36 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/frommersbeijing00brow/page/36/ |text='''Xicheng''' The sector immediately west of the Forbidden City, '''Xicheng''' is the site of some of the most extensive old ''hutong'' (alleyway) neighborhoods left in Beijing.}} #* {{quote-web |en |date=30 October 2021 |title=China cracks down over 'serious' Covid outbreak |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20211030113447/https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20211030-china-cracks-down-over-serious-covid-outbreak |archivedate=30 October 2021 |work={{w|France 24}} |text=In Beijing, authorities ordered all cinemas closed until November 14 in the capital's '''Xicheng''' district, which lies west of Tiananmen Square and is home to over a million people.}} #* {{seemoreCites|en}} # a [[subdistrict]] in [[Zengdu]], [[Suizhou]], [[Hubei]], [[China]] # a [[subdistrict]] in [[Jingzhou]], [[Jingzhou]], [[Hubei]], [[China]] ====Translations==== {{trans-top|district; subdistricts}} * Chinese: *: Mandarin: {{t|cmn|西城|tr=Xīchéng|sc=Hani}} {{trans-mid}} * Japanese: {{t-needed|ja}} {{trans-bottom}} ===See also=== * {{l|en|Dongcheng}} [[Category:en:Places in China]]

page.text: ==English== ===Etymology=== Alteration of "piece X" read upside down. ===Noun=== {{en-noun}} # {{lb|en|rare}} A [[parallelogram]]-shaped [[connector]] in a [[model]] [[rocket]] assembly. #* '''2000''', "Scott D. Orr", ''Re: Questions about Boost Glider Boosts [Again--Someone answer, please!]'' (on newsgroup ''rec.models.rockets'') #*: There could be some side-to-side movement, because the piece the glider fuselage was cut from is actually a bit narrower than the piece the pod pylon was cut from (and I think the '''xerclod''' is a bit narrower than the fuselage, though I've built that part up with tape). #* '''2000''', "Rhhickok", ''Re: Motor mount burn through'' (on newsgroup ''rec.models.rockets'') #*: Each side of the BT-60 had 2 '''xerclods''' (short lengths of 1/8" dowels) to hang the gliders on. #* '''2002''', "Bob Kaplow", ''RMR FAQ part 8.2 Free Flight Boost Gliders [long]'' (on newsgroup ''rec.models.rockets'') #*: Some sort of positive hook is needed, yet it must be designed to separate easily at ejection. Once{{SIC}} common method is the "Piece X" or '''xerclod''' hook, where a rhombus hook is cut from the fuselage and attached to the pop pod.

page.title: Xenaphile
page.text: ==English== ===Etymology=== {{suffix|en|Xena|phile}} ===Noun=== {{en-noun}} # {{lb|en|fandom slang}} A [[fan]] of the [[television]] series ''{{w|Xena: Warrior Princess}}''. #* '''1998''', Greg Cox, ''Battle On!: An Unauthorized, Irreverent Look at Xena: Warrior Princess'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=6CZ33h6L8LAC&q=%22xenaphiles%22& page 8]: #*: {{...}} but devout '''Xenaphiles''' end up squinting at blurry, freeze-framed images on their TV screens in hopes of finding out which mythological entity was not injured or otherwise inconvenienced this week. #* '''1998''', Heather Findlay, "Xena-philia!", ''Girlfriends'', April 1998, page 29: #*: In light of this inexplicit story line — what gay and straight '''Xenaphiles''' refer to casually as "the subtext" — the opening voice-over's weekly refrain, "In a time of ancient gods, warlords, and kings," begins to sound gendered. #* '''1999''', ''Cinefantastique'', Volume 31, Issues 1-6, [https://books.google.com/books?id=8oBZAAAAMAAJ&q=%22xenaphile%22 page 3]: #*: New York correspondent and '''Xenaphile''' Dan Scapperotti provides this issue's look behind-the-scenes at the making of the show, including an exclusive interview with New Zealand star Lucy Lawless. #* {{seemoreCites|en}} ====Synonyms==== * {{l|en|Xenite}} ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=aeehilnpx|lexiphane}} [[Category:English eponyms]] [[Category:en:Fans (people)]] [[Category:en:Xena: Warrior Princess]]

page.title: xaltetl
page.text: ==Classical Nahuatl== ===Etymology=== From {{compound|nci|xālli|tetl|t1=sand|t2=rock, stone}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|nci|/ˈʃaːɬtet͡ɬ/}} ===Noun=== {{nci-noun|i|xāltetl}} # [[gravel]], [[pebble]]s #* '''1555''', [[w:Alonso de Molina|Alonso de Molina]], ''[[w:Aquí comiença un vocabulario en la lengua castellana y mexicana|Aqui comienca vn vocabulario en la lengua castellana y mexicana]]'', f. 45v. #*: Caſcajo otro.   '''xaltetl'''. #*:: Another [kind of] gravel.   '''xaltetl'''. #* '''1571''', ''Idem'', ''[[w:Vocabulario en lengua castellana y mexicana y mexicana y castellana|Vocabulario en lengua castellana y mexicana y mexicana y castellana]]'', f. 158v. col. 1. #*: '''Xaltetl''' china o piedrezuela. #*:: '''Xaltetl''' a pebble or small rock. ====Synonyms==== * {{l|nci|tetzicuehualli|tetzicuēhualli}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|nci|xaltetlah|xāltetlah}} * {{l|nci|xaxalteyoh|xāxālteyoh}} ===References=== * {{cite-book|author=[[w:Alonso de Molina|Alonso de Molina]]|year=2008|title=[[w:Vocabulario en lengua castellana y mexicana y mexicana y castellana|Vocabulario en lengua castellana y mexicana y mexicana y castellana]] (1571)|publisher=Editorial Porrúa|page=158}}

page.text: {{also|xanthe}} ==English== ===Etymology=== From {{bor|en|grc|Ξανθή|lit=blond-haired}}, from {{m|grc|ξανθός|t=yellow}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|en|/ˈzænθi/}} * {{hyph|en|Xan|the}} ===Proper noun=== {{en-proper noun}} # {{lb|en|rare}} {{given name|en|female|from=Ancient Greek}}. #* '''2009''', {{w|Anne Tyler}}, ''Noah's Compass'', Vintage {{ISBN|9780099539582}}, page 165: #*: "So that was '''Xanthe'''," she said in a musing tone. #*: "You're thinking it's a misnomer ,aren't you," Liam said. #*: "What?" #*: "'''Xanthe'''. It means 'golden'." #*: "Well, I'm sure she's very pleasant as a rule." #*: Liam had been referring to '''Xanthe's''' coloring―her brown hair and level dark eyebrows. #* '''2012''', {{w|Anna Jacobs}}, ''The Trader's Dream'', Hachette UK {{ISBN|9781444714685}} #*: Maura looked at her in bafflement. What had this to do with her? She knew no one called '''Xanthe'''. What sort of name was that, anyway? ---- ==Latin== ===Proper noun=== {{la-proper noun-form|Xanthe}} # {{inflection of|la|Xanthus||voc|s}}

The {{w|International Mineralogical Association}}'s Commission on New Minerals, Nomenclature and Classification (CNMNC) recommends using [[clintonite]] as a replacement in all cases.<ref>{{cite-journal|author=<!--over ten authors-->|title=Nomenclature of the Micas|journal=The Canadian Mineralogist|url=http://www.canmin.org/content/36/3/905.full.pdf+html|publisher=The Mineralogical Association of Canada|year=1998|volume=36|issue=3|pages=905-912|issn=1499-1276|oclc=818930682|subscription=y}}</ref> ====Synonyms==== * [[clintonite]] ====References==== <references/> ===Further reading=== * {{R:WebMineral}} * {{R:mindat}} [[Category:English terms prefixed with xantho-]]

page.text: ==English== ===Etymology=== {{confix|en|xeno|phone}} ===Pronunciation=== * {{a|UK}} {{IPA|en|/ˈzɛn.ə.fəʊn/}} ===Noun=== {{en-noun}} # {{lb|en|phonetics}} A [[sound]] in speech that is not native to the language being spoken; a sound from a foreign language ===References=== The term was introduced in: [http://roberteklund.info Robert Eklund] & Anders Lindström. 1998. How To Handle “Foreign” Sounds in Swedish Text-to-Speech Conversion: Approaching the ‘Xenophone’ Problem. ''Proceedings of The International Conference on Spoken Language Processing'', 30 November–5 December 1998, Sydney, Australia. Paper 514, vol. 7, pp. 2831–2834. [https://web.archive.org/web/20050518114442/http://www.ida.liu.se/~g-robek/icslp98xeno.pdf] Also see: [http://xenophones.info] http://xenophones.info

page.title: xenalipin
xenarthran
page.text: ==English== [[File:Southern Three Banded Armadillo 001-2.jpg|right|thumb|A southern three-banded armadillo (''Tolypeutes matacus''), a xenarthran]] {{wikipedia|Xenarthra}} ===Etymology=== From {{uder|en|grc|ξένος||strange}} + {{m|grc|ἄρθρον||joint}}. ===Noun=== {{en-noun}} # {{lb|en|zoology}} Any mammal of the of superorder [[Xenarthra]], of the Americas; an [[anteater]], [[armadillo]] or [[sloth]]. #* '''1978''', Terry A. Vaughan, James M. Ryan, Nicholas J. Czaplewski, ''Mammalogy'', [https://books.google.com.au/books?id=96HuAAAAMAAJ&q=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&dq=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=12VQVan6EMLBmAXtzIHYDg&ved=0CKgDEOgBMEw page 355], #*: Elephant-shrews, '''xenarthrans''', hystricognathous rodents, cetaceans, some pinnipeds, and primates depart sharply from this trend, however. #* '''2000''', John F. Eisenberg, Kent H. Redford, ''Mammals of the Neotropics'', Volume 3: Ecuador, Bolivia, Brazil, [https://books.google.com.au/books?id=p2MDAzCeQQoC&pg=PA90&dq=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=12VQVan6EMLBmAXtzIHYDg&ved=0CHkQ6AEwEw#v=onepage&q=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&f=false page 90], #*: '''Xenarthrans''' appear to have originated in South America and to have undergone their major adaptive radiation there (Reig 1981). #* '''2008''', Christine Argot, ''3: Changing Views in Paleontology: The Story of a Giant (Megatherium, Xenarthra)'', Eric J. Sargis, Marian Dagosto (editors), ''Mammalian Evolutionary Morphology: A Tribute to Frederick S. Szalay'', [https://books.google.com.au/books?id=6_n2Sr7kIO8C&pg=PA37&dq=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=12VQVan6EMLBmAXtzIHYDg&ved=0CIACEOgBMCs#v=onepage&q=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&f=false page 37], #*: Only four '''xenarthran''' families are extant today, providing little indication of the past richness of the order. #* '''2010''', Ana Maria Jansen, André Luiz Rodrigues Roque, ''11: Domestic and Wild Mammalian Reservoirs'', Jenny Telleria, Michel Tibayrenc, ''American Trypanosomiasis: Chagas Disease: One Hundred Years of Research'', [https://books.google.com.au/books?id=sXL_ESJ_Zl4C&pg=PA249&dq=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=12VQVan6EMLBmAXtzIHYDg&ved=0CIABEOgBMBQ#v=onepage&q=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&f=false page 249], #*: Marsupials and '''xenarthrans''', which represented the autochthonous mammalian fauna, were ''T.<sup>[Trypanosoma]</sup> cruzi''’s first hosts. ====Usage notes==== The '''xenarthrans''' were previously included within now obsolete ([[polyphyletic]]) order [[Edentata]], along with [[aardvark]]s and [[pangolin]]s. ====Hypernyms==== * {{sense|any species of Xenarthra}} {{l|en|edentate}} {{qualifier|obsolete classification}} ====Hyponyms==== * {{sense|any species of Xenarthra}} {{l|en|anteater}}, {{l|en|armadillo}}, {{l|en|glyptodont}}, [[pampathere]], [[sloth]] ====Derived terms==== * [[xenarthrous]] ====Translations==== {{trans-top|mammal}} * French: {{t+|fr|xénarthre|m}} {{trans-mid}} * Italian: {{t+|it|xenartro|m}} * Polish: {{t|pl|szczerbak|m}} {{trans-bottom}} [[Category:en:Mammals]]

page.text: {{see also|xìcháng|Xīchāng}} ==English== {{wikipedia}} {{commonscat}} ===Alternative forms=== * {{q|from [[Wade–Giles]]}} {{l|en|Hsi-ch'ang}} ===Etymology=== From the {{bor|en|cmn-pinyin|-}} romanization of {{uder|en|zh|西昌||[[western|Western]] [[prosperity|Prosperity]]|tr=Xīchāng}}. ===Pronunciation=== {{rfp|en}} ===Proper noun=== {{en-proper noun}} # {{place|en|county-level city|autonomous prefecture/Liangshan|p/Sichuan|c/China}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=1954 |last=Wiens |first=Herold J. |title=Han Chinese Expansion in South China |url=https://archive.org/details/hanchineseexpans0000wien/ |publisher=Shoe String Press |year_published=1967 |LCCN=67-16409 |OCLC=473651484 |page=290 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/hanchineseexpans0000wien/page/290/ |text=Chao-erh-feng planned some fundamental measures to control the Lolo, including the construction of a through road between Lei-po and '''Hsi-ch'ang'''. Up to the present this has not been accomplished, however. The '''Hsi-ch'ang''' sector was finished as far as Chao-chio city and beyond to Yeh-lu-na-ta. |brackets=on}} #* {{quote-journal |en |year=1978 |month=February |title=The Long March (II) |journal=Eastern Horizon |url=https://archive.org/details/sim_eastern-horizon_1978-02_17_2/ |volume=XVII |issue=2 |location=[[Hong Kong]] |publisher=Eastern Horizon Press |issn=0012-8813 |oclc=751117974 |page=39 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/sim_eastern-horizon_1978-02_17_2/page/39/ |column=2 |text=After a five-day rest at Huili, the Red Army continued its drive northward. Passing through the Yi nationality area of Tehchang, '''Hsichang''' the vanguard troops led by Liu Po-cheng made an alliance with the chieftains of the Kuchi tribe, and managed to neutralize the Laowu tribe. |brackets=on}} ====Synonyms==== * {{sense|historic}} {{l|en|Jiandu}}; {{l|en|Jianchang}} ====Translations==== {{trans-top}} * Chinese: *: Mandarin: {{t+|cmn|西昌|tr=Xīchāng}} {{trans-mid}} * Sichuan Yi: {{t|ii|ꀒꎂ}} {{trans-bottom}}

Xianity
page.text: ==English== ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|en|Xtianity}} ===Etymology=== From {{m|en|Christianity}}, replacing {{m|en|Christ}} with the abbreviation {{m|en|X}}, from {{uder|en|grc|Χ||pos=the letter chi}}, the first letter of {{m|grc|Χριστός||[[Christ]]}}. Compare the more common {{m|en|Xmas}}. ===Noun=== {{en-noun|-}} # {{abbreviation of|en|Christianity}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=1861 |title=Sussex Archaeological Collections relating to the History and Antiquities of the County |volume=13 |author=Sussex Archaeological Society |publisher=George P. Bacon |location=Sussex |quotee=Vicar of Rye |page=62 |pageurl=http://books.google.com/books?id=SDcGAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA62&dq=xianity |passage=Not but that I perswade myselfe to bee able to convince you (if you list to undergoe yo<sup>r</sup> triall) how interolerable an injury it is you doe y<sup>r</sup>selfe, in y<sup>e</sup> first place, y<sup>r</sup> ignorant followers, y<sup>e</sup> King's authority, y<sup>e</sup> credit of the towne, and y<sup>e</sup> progress of '''Xianity''' in general, in these parts, by y<sup>r</sup> schisme and separation. }} #* '''1950''' December 14, [[w:C. S. Lewis|Lewis, C. S.]], letter to Sheldon Vanauken, quoted in ''Sleuthing C. S. Lewis'' by Kathryn Ann Lindskoog: #*: I believe Buddhism to be a simplification of Hinduism and Islam to be a simplification of '''Xianity'''. ====Usage notes==== As with {{m|en|Xmas}}, as of the late 20th century this term may be considered informal or disrespectful. ====Related terms==== * {{l|en|Xian}} * {{l|en|Xmas}} * {{l|en|Xtianity}} [[Category:en:Christianity]]

page.title: xenobiosis
Xiantao
page.text:
{{also|xiāntáo}} ==English== {{wikipedia}} {{commonscat}} ===Alternative forms=== * {{q|from [[Wade–Giles]]}} {{l|en|Hsien-t'ao}} ===Etymology=== From the {{bor|en|cmn-pinyin|-}} romanization of the {{bor|en|cmn|-}} pronunciation for {{zh-l|仙桃|Xiāntáo}}. ===Pronunciation=== {{rfp|en}} ===Proper noun=== {{en-proper noun}} # {{place|en|sub-prefecture-level city|p/Hubei|c/China}}. #* {{quote-journal |en |year=1981 |month=July |last=Alley |first=Rewi |authorlink=Rewi Alley |title=Flood Strikes again in Hubei |journal=Eastern Horizon |url=https://archive.org/details/sim_eastern-horizon_1981-07_20_7/ |volume=XX |issue=7 |location=[[Hong Kong]] |publisher=Eastern Horizon Press |issn=0012-8813 |oclc=751117974 |page=13 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/sim_eastern-horizon_1981-07_20_7/page/13/ |text=Wuhan grows steadily, changing its face quite a bit each year one comes. Hanyang spreads out, and Mianyang, where we halted for a meal and rest, at its county town of '''Xiantao''', which is now becoming a modern city.}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=2001 |month=February |last=Hattaway |first=Paul |title=China's Unreached Cities |url=https://archive.org/details/chinasunreachedc0001hatt/ |volume=1 |location=[[Chiang Mai]], [[Thailand]] |publisher=Darawan Printing |ISBN=974-85303-8-8 |OCLC=43922815 |OL=9183612M |page=100 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/chinasunreachedc0001hatt/page/100/ |text=Residing on the banks of the Hanshui River in south-central Hubei Province are more than 1.8 million inhabitants of '''Xiantao''' City. The central city area itself may only have about 250,000 people, but '''Xiantao''' has jurisdiction over a number of sprawling suburbs and surrounding villages which pushes its population up. Because of improved roads, '''Xiantao''' is now only a 50-minute drive from the provincial capital, Wuhan.}} #* {{quote-web |en |date=June 27, 2016 |last=Rajagopalan |first=Megha |title=China city shuts down waste-burning plant project over protests |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160628155419/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-protests-idUSKCN0ZD0HU |archivedate=28 June 2016 |work={{w|Reuters}} |text=The mayor of a city in central China made a rare public address calling for calm after thousands of people protested against a waste incineration project over fears it would damage the environment and residents' health.{{...}}
The city of '''Xiantao''', in Hubei province, said on Sunday it would suspend the project but protests continued on Monday.}} #* {{seemoreCites|en}} ====Translations==== {{trans-top|sub-prefecture-level city in central China}} * Chinese: *: Mandarin: {{t+|cmn|仙桃|tr=Xiāntáo|sc=Hani}} {{trans-mid}} * Japanese: {{t-needed|ja}} {{trans-bottom}}

page.title: Xiangzhou
page.text: ==English== {{wikipedia}} ===Alternative forms=== * {{q|from [[Wade–Giles]]}} {{l|en|Hsiang-chou}} ===Etymology=== From the {{bor|en|cmn-pinyin|-}} romanization of the {{bor|en|cmn|-}} pronunciation for {{zh-l|襄州}}. ===Pronunciation=== {{rfp|en}} ===Proper noun=== {{en-proper noun}} # {{place|en|district|prefecture-level city/Xiangyang|p/Hubei|c/China}}. #* {{quote-web |en |date=01/29/2016 |author=Editorial Office |title=Chenghe Wickerwork |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20220730142212/https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache%3Ahttp%3A%2F%2Fen.hubei.gov.cn%2Fculture%2Fintangible%2F201601%2Ft20160129_1412132.shtml |archivedate=30 July 2022 |work=Hubei Provincial People's Government Official Web Portal |url=http://en.hubei.gov.cn/culture/intangible/201601/t20160129_1412132.shtml |text=Chenghe wickerwork, also known as Xiangyang wickerwork, is a specialty of Chenghe town<!--程河镇-->, '''Xiangzhou''' district, Xiangyang city, and a product with protected geographical indication in China. Chenghe is one of the top three wickerwork export bases in China.}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=2021 |last=Ge |first=Jianxiong |last2=Hu |first2=Yunsheng |title=A Historical Survey of the Yellow River and the River Civilizations |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iiASEAAAQBAJ |ISBN=978-981-33-4480-8 |ISSN=2196-3134 |OCLC=1201384776 |page=184 |text=Northern Hubei was centered around '''Xiangzhou''', Xiangyang (modern Xiangfan of Hubei), the seat of local government of '''Xiangzhou''', was a major gathering point for southward emigration out of the Central Plains due to its location at the intersection between the Han River and the trunk road from Nanyang to Jiangling.}} ====Translations==== {{trans-top|district in central China}} * Chinese: *: Mandarin: {{t+|cmn|襄州|tr=Xiāngzhōu|sc=Hani}} {{trans-mid}} * Japanese: {{t-needed|ja}} {{trans-bottom}}

page.title: xeer
page.text: ==English== ===Noun=== {{en-noun|-}} {{wikipedia}} # The [[traditional]] [[legal]] system of [[Somalia]], believed to [[predate]] [[Islam]], in which [[elder]]s serve as [[mediator]]s and people are responsible for the actions of their families. #* {{quote-book|en|year=1977|author=David D Laitin|title=Politics, language, and thought: the Somali experience|passage=It arranges for settlement of collective debts, discusses '''xeer''' dealings with central authorities, maintains the group wells, and protects grazing areas.}} #* '''2005''', Walter Dostal, Wolfgang Kraus, ''Shattering tradition: custom, law and the individual in the Muslim Mediterranean'' #*: In rural areas, there is still confusion between '''xeer''' and shari'a. #* '''2007''', Lars Buur, Helene Maria Kyed, ''State recognition and democratization in Sub-Saharan Africa'' #*: The key feature of the '''xeer''' is its common law character... ---- ==Wolof== ===Etymology=== Possibly cognate with {{cog|ff|hayre||stone}}. ===Noun=== {{wo-noun|wi}} # [[stone]], [[rock]] ===References=== {{cite-book |author=Omar Ka |chapter= |title=Nanu Dégg Wolof |publisher=National African Language Resource Center |year=2018 |page=259 |isbn=978-1-59703-017-5}}

page.text: ==English== ===Etymology=== From {{confix|en|xanth|emia}}. ===Noun=== {{en-noun|-}} # {{lb|en|pathology}} The occurrence of [[yellow]] matter in the [[blood]]. #* '''1902''', Heinrich Stern, Journal of the American Medical Association, Volume 38, ''On the treatment of obesity''<sup>[http://books.google.com/books?id=mVPlAAAAMAAJ]</sup>: #*: Among the latter, incipient nephritis and metabolic anomalies, as '''xanthemia''', arthritis uritica, oxaluria are common. #* '''1922''', Leroy Sheldon Palmer, ''Carotinoids and related pigments: the chromolipoids'', page 136<sup>[http://books.google.com/books?id=_dUKAAAAIAAJ]</sup>: #*: Carotin was inferred, not demonstrated, in these cases, although Salomon measured the extent of the "'''xanthemia'''" in certain individuals by determining the extinction coefficient of the absorption bands of the ether extract of the blood. # {{lb|en|pathology}} The occurrence of [[yellow]] skin #* '''1976''', Denis Llewellyn Fox, ''Animal biochromes and structural colours: physical, chemical, distributional'', page 174<sup>[http://books.google.com/books?id=tti9WX3lL70C]</sup>: #*: False jaundice or carotenemia ('''xanthemia''') is an unusual and abnormal yellowness of the human skin, sometimes actually appearing in the sweat, resulting from the ingestion of carotenoid-rich food such as carrots, oranges or yellow cucurbits in large quantities over protracted periods. ====Synonyms==== * {{l|en|carotenemia}} ====Related terms==== * {{l|en|xanthosis}}

Xianggang
page.text: {{also|Xiānggǎng}} ==English== ===Alternative forms=== * {{q|from [[Wade–Giles]]}} {{l|en|Hsiang Kang}} ===Etymology=== From the {{bor|en|cmn-pinyin|-}} romanization of {{bor|en|cmn|-}} {{zh-m|香港}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|en|/ʃjɑːŋˈɡɑːŋ/}} ===Proper noun=== {{en-proper noun}} # {{lb|en|rare}} {{synonym of|en|Hong Kong}} {{qualifier|especially in the Chinese English language media}} #* {{quote-journal |en |url=https://archive.org/details/militaryreview617usar/ |year=1981 |month=July |title=A Look at the British Regimental System |author=Robert S. B. Watson |journal={{w|Military Review}} |volume=LXI |issue=7 |page=55 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/militaryreview617usar/page/55/}} #*:At the end of that period, it may move to Northern Ireland for two years and then from there to '''Xianggang''' for two years, with internal security roles in both places. #* {{quote-book |en |year=1982 |author=Anthony B. Chan |title=Arming the Chinese: The Western Armaments Trade in Warlord China, 1920-1928 |url=https://archive.org/details/armingchinesewes0000chan/ |location=[[Vancouver]] |publisher={{w|University of British Columbia Press}} |ISBN=0-7748-0157-3 |OCLC=490855225 |OL=3216321M |page=105 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/armingchinesewes0000chan/page/105/ |passage=Like Shanghai, Qingdao, Qinhuangdao, and Yingkou, Guangzhou provided easy access for Western ships entering warlord China. Specifically, Guangzhou with its links to '''Xianggang''' was the ideal receiver base for war munitions into south China. '''Xianggang''', in turn, was connected to Portuguese Aomen (Macao) and Manila with its American overseers.}} #* '''2004''', Philip Bowring, ''International Herald Tribune'', April 22, 2004 #*: The truly politically correct, however, will already be writing Hong Kong not just as one word but as '''Xianggang'''. That is the official version in pinyin, mainland China's version of romanization. ====Translations==== {{trans-see|Hong Kong}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Merriam Webster Online}} * {{R:Dictionary.com}} [[Category:en:Cities]]

page.text: {{also|XE|Xe|хе|xé|xè|xế|xê|xẻ}} ==English== {{wikipedia|xe (pronoun)}} ===Etymology=== Apparently independently invented by several people, including Don Rickter (the pronoun appeared in the Unitarian Universalist publication ''UU World'' on 1 May 1973 and Mario Pei gave Rickter credit on page 145 of his 1978 book ''Weasel Words''). ===Pronunciation=== * {{a|UK}} {{enPR|zē|hē|ksē}}, {{IPA|en|/ziː/|/hiː/|/ksiː/}} * {{a|US}} {{enPR|zē|hē|ksē}}, {{IPA|en|/zi/|/hi/|/ksi/}} * {{rhymes|en|iː|s=1}} * {{hmp|en|he|z}} ===Pronoun=== {{en-pron}} # {{lb|en|nonstandard}} they {{qualifier|singular}}. {{non-gloss definition|[[gender-neutral|Gender-neutral]] third-person singular subject pronoun, coordinate with gendered pronouns {{m|en|he}} and {{m|en|she}}.}} #* {{quote-web |en |year=1992 |first=Jim |last=Sinclair |title=If you could choose... |site=Jim Sinclair's Web Site |url=http://web.syr.edu/~jisincla/choice.htm |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20031103004908/http://web.syr.edu/~jisincla/choice.htm |archivedate=2003-11-03 |passage=Anyone I would be interested in would have to be a pretty special person. I wouldn't want to miss out on knowing such a person just because '''xe''' happened to be the "wrong" sex. }} #* {{quote-newsgroup |en |date=1993-09-14 |first=Jim |last=Sinclair |title=Re: Jim and Steve's snoring discussion |newsgroup=bit.listserv.autism |id=AUTISM%93091417074261@SJUVM.STJOHNS.EDU |url=https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups#!msg/bit.listserv.autism/2pyrOMzt_nQ/5J-RU5P3hnIJ |passage=Telepathy would require that you share the other person's knowledge of [[xyr]] own mind, which in turn requires recognizing that '''xe''' is actually aware of what '''xe''''s thinking, which is incompatible with psychiatry. }} #* {{quote-newsgroup |en |date=1999-04-28 |first=Dagmar |last=Alpen |title=Re: Think of a small tribe of people... |newsgroup=talk.politics.libertarian |id=7g74qb$8sq$1@rzsun02.rrz.uni-hamburg.de |url=https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups#!msg/talk.politics.libertarian/Wxi8N4PwnW0/yRrhhmYAGygJ |passage=Now full ownership in the modern sense... implies four rights of the owner: 1. The right to decide what '''xe''' does with [[xyr]] property; 2. the right to decide what others do with xyr property; {{...}} }} #* {{quote-newsgroup |en |date=2000-12-11 |title=Silencing and ad hominem attacks |first=Mary Ellen |last=Curtin |newsgroup=alt.startrek.creative.erotica.moderated |id=074d01c06393$c1a2fb00$5be9cfcf@default |url=http://groups.google.com/group/alt.startrek.creative.erotica.moderated/msg/3a23ecdc585ca8b1 |passage=Since '''xe''' went to the trouble of re-posting, I figured it was about something of more than usual importance to [[hir]]... I wrote to EmGee privately and '''xe''' said yes, that was one of the things '''xe''' was talking about. }} #* {{quote-newsgroup |en |date=2002-03-03 |title=Re: Newbie...not quite sure yet... |first=Ken |last=von Mattell |newsgroup=alt.suicide.holiday |id=rif48uc0ja9q3km9o2jf167d4u4o3qpk1k@4ax.com |url=https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups#!msg/alt.suicide.holiday/azDueNoiilA/JtxS4uc12pkJ |passage=I mean, suppose there's someone who can't leave the house because '''xe''''s all tied up with counting tiles in the bathroom all day, and if '''xe''' manages to get done with that, there's the stove to check again and again ... you get the idea. }} ====Declension==== * Subject: '''xe''' (or [[xhe]]) * Object: [[xem]] (or [[xer]]) * Possessive: [[xyr]] or [[xir]] (or [[xis]] or [[xer]]) (or [[xeir]]) * Reflexive: [[xyrself]] or [[xirself]] (perhaps rarely [[xemself]] or [[hirself]] or [[xerself]]) ====Synonyms==== * {{qualifier|singular}} [[they]] * {{qualifier|neologism}} [[e]], [[ey]], [[sie]], [[ze]], [[per]] ====Hyponyms==== * {{l|en|he}}, {{l|en|she}} ====See also==== * [[Appendix:English third-person singular pronouns]] ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=ex|-ex|ex|ex-|ex.}} {{cln|en|third person pronouns}} {{c|en|Non-binary}} ---- ==Cypriot Arabic== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|acy|ar|أَخَذَ}}. ===Verb=== {{head|acy|verb|present|pkyaxo}} # to [[take]] # to [[catch fire]] ---- ==Drehu== ===Etymology=== Compare {{cog|axx|sa||hit}}. ===Verb=== {{head|dhv|verb}} # [[smack]] ===References=== * Claire Moyse-Faurie, ''Constructions expressing middle, reflexive and reciprocal situations in some Oceanic languages'', in ''Reciprocals and Reflexives: Theoretical and Typological Explorations'' ---- ==Ewe== ===Adjective=== {{head|ee|adjective}} # [[hoarse]] ===Noun=== {{head|ee|noun}} # [[bird]] ===Verb=== {{head|ee|verb}} # to [[block]] so that it is not possible to pass / to prevent (something or someone) from passing # to [[catch]] (a ball) # to [[fill]], to make full # to [[seal]], to prevent people or vehicles from crossing (something) or to close (it) securely to prevent leakage [[Category:ee:Birds]] ---- ==Ido== ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|io|/kse/|/ksɛ/}} ===Noun=== {{head|io|noun|plural|xe-i}} # {{non-gloss definition|The name of the [[Appendix:Latin script|Latin script]] letter '''[[X]]'''/'''[[x]]'''.}} ====See also==== * {{list:Latin script letter names/io}} ---- ==Middle English== ===Pronoun=== {{head|enm|pronoun}} # {{lb|enm|chiefly southern East Midland dialectal}} {{alt form|enm|sche}} [[Category:East Midland Middle English]] ---- ==Paipai== ===Noun=== {{head|ppi|noun}} # [[pot]], [[kettle]] [[Category:ppi:Cookware and bakeware]] [[Category:ppi:Vessels]] ---- ==Venetian== ===Verb=== {{head|vec|verb form}} # {{inflection of|vec|èser||3|s|pres|indc}} # {{inflection of|vec|èser||3|p|pres|indc}} ---- ==Vietnamese== ===Pronunciation=== {{vi-ipa}} ===Etymology 1=== {{vi-etym-sino|車|preMC=y|[[vehicle]]|xa}}. Compare {{m|vi|hè}} and {{m|vi|hạ}}, {{m|vi|chè}} and {{m|vi|trà}}. ====Noun==== {{vi-noun|cls=[[chiếc]]; [[con]]|車}} # [[wheeled]] [[vehicle]] {{gl|except for [[airplane]]s}} #: {{syn|vi|xế}} #: {{uxi|vi|đậu xe|to park}} #: {{uxi|vi|lái xe|to pilot a wheeled vehicle other than planes or trains; to drive, to ride, etc.}} =====Usage notes===== This term includes [[steam train]]s ({{m|vi|xe lửa}}) in Southern Vietnam but not in Northern Vietnam, where they are classified as {{m|vi|tàu}} ({{m|vi|tàu hỏa}}). =====Derived terms===== {{vi-der|bánh xe|bằng lái xe|bến xe|bến xe buýt|cỗ xe|dấu xe ngựa|đẩy xe|giấy phép lái xe|gọng xe|hòm xe|kẹt xe|lái xe|loại từ vòng gửi xe|lơ xe|ngựa xe như nước|nhà xe|nhíp xe|phu xe|ruột xe|say xe|thùng xe|toa xe|tông xe|trạm xe lửa|xe ba bánh|xe ba gác|xe bán tải|xe ben|xe bình bịch|xe bò|xe bọc thép|xe buýt|xe ca|xe cải tiến|xe cam nhông|xe cam-nhông|xe cấp cứu|xe chữa cháy|xe công nông|xe cộ|xe cúp|xe cút kít|xe cứu hỏa|xe cứu thương|xe dây|xe đẩy hàng|xe du lịch|xe đạp|xe đạp bánh béo|xe điện|xe điện ngầm|xe đò|xe đòn|xe độc mã|xe gắn máy|xe goòng|xe gíp|xe hai bánh|xe hàng|xe hoa|xe hỏa|xe hòm|xe Honda|xe hon đa|xe hơi|xe hương|xe kéo|xe khách|xe lai|xe lai sạc điện|xe lam|xe lăn|xe lăn đường|xe lôi|xe lội nước|xe lu|xe lửa|xe lửa cao tốc|xe máy|xe mô tô|xe mô-tô|xe ngựa|xe nôi|xe ô-tô|xe ôm|xe pháo|xe rác|xe rùa|xe song mã|xe tải|xe tang|xe tay|xe tắc xi|xe tắc-xi|xe tăng|xe tứ mã|xe tưới đường|xe thiết giáp|xe thổ mộ|xe thư|xe trượt tuyết|xe ủi đất|xe vận tải|xe xích lô|xuống xe}} =====Descendants===== * {{desc|blt|ꪵꪎ}} ====Noun==== {{vi-noun|cls=con|車}} # {{lb|vi|xiangqi}} [[chariot]], a [[piece]] labeled with the characters {{m|zh|車|pos=black|tr=xa}} and {{m|zh|俥|pos=red}} # {{lb|vi|by extension|chess}} [[rook]] =====See also===== {{table:chess pieces/vi}} ===Etymology 2=== ====Adjective==== {{vi-adj}} # {{lb|vi|obsolete}} [[many]] {{topics|vi|Vehicles|Board games}}

Xenaverse
page.text: ==English== ===Etymology=== {{suffix|en|Xena|verse}} ===Proper noun=== {{en-proper noun}} # {{lb|en|fandom slang}} The [[fictional]] [[universe]] depicted in the ''{{w|Xena: Warrior Princess}}'' series. #* '''1998''', Greg Cox, ''Battle On!: An Unauthorized, Irreverent Look at Xena: Warrior Princess'', [https://books.google.ca/books?id=6CZ33h6L8LAC&q=%22xenaverse%22 page 88]: #*: Guess things are different in the '''Xenaverse'''. Maybe Ares and the other gods don't like competition? #* '''2005''', "Doris", quoted in Sue Austin, ''Women's Aggressive Fantasies: A Post-Jungian Exploration of Self-hatred, Love and Agency'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=GJnS9dWas6YC&pg=PA222&dq=%22women+in+the+xenaverse%22 page 22]: #*: The show is an amazing foray into women's expressions of rage — there's a lot of other women in the '''Xenaverse''' with a penchant for feats of arms {{...}} #* '''2013''', Jennifer Sky, "[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/10/opinion/my-life-as-a-warrior-princess.html?hp&_r=0 My Life as a Warrior Princess]", ''The New York Times'', 9 September 2013: #*: Gender was not relevant in the '''Xenaverse'''. There, a girl or a boy could be a warlord or a farmer, a bard or a sad sack needing protection. #* {{seemoreCites|en}} # {{lb|en|fandom slang}} The [[fandom]] of ''[[w:Xena: Warrior Princess|Xena: Warrior Princess]]''. #* '''2002''', Jo Marriott & Carly Bramwell, "Maid Marion, Meet Xena", in ''How Xena Changed Our Lives: True Stories by Fans for Fans'' (ed. Nikki Stafford), [https://books.google.com/books?id=5VWV7xmyV3IC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22part+of+the+xenaverse%22 page 72]: #*: Many wonderful people and events have come into our lives from being part of the '''Xenaverse'''. #* '''2003''', Sara Gwellian-Jones, "Histories, Fictions and ''Xena: Warrior Princess''", in ''The Audience Studies Reader'' (eds. Will Brooker & Deborah Jermyn), [https://books.google.com/books?id=MzlGK4BRGTUC&pg=PA187&dq=%22online+xenaverse+is%22 page 188]: #*: The task of mapping the online '''Xenaverse''' is, of course, an impossible one. The '''Xenaverse''' is too expansive, too unstructured, too fluid and fast moving to be charted; {{...}} #* '''2005''', Anik LaChev, "Fan Fiction: A Genre And Its (Final?) Frontiers", ''Spectator'', Volume 25, Number 1, Spring 2005, [https://books.google.com/books?id=0bAqAQAAIAAJ&q=%22xenaverse%22&dq=%22xenaverse%22 page 91]: #*: For instance, when I lived in Italy a couple of years ago, I stumbled across the Italian '''Xenaverse'''. #* {{seemoreCites|en}} ====See also==== * {{l|en|Hercverse}} [[Category:English 3-syllable words]] [[Category:English eponyms]] [[Category:en:Fandom]] [[Category:en:Fictional universes]] [[Category:en:Xena: Warrior Princess]]

xanthophobia
page.text: ==English== ===Etymology=== From {{confix|en|xantho|phobia}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{a|US}} {{IPA | en |/zæn.θəˈfoʊ.bi.ə/}} *: {{rhymes|en|əʊbiə|s=5}} ===Noun=== {{en-noun|-}} # {{lb|en|rare}} An [[aversion]] to [[yellow]] light. #* '''1991''', Blair E. Witherington and Karen A. Bjorndal, “[http://www.jstor.org/stable/1446101 Influences of Wavelength and Intensity on Hatchling Sea Turtle Phototaxis: Implications for Sea-Finding Behavior]”, in ''[[w:Copeia|Copeia]]'', Volume 1991, Number 4 (December 13), American Society of Ichthyologists and Herpetologists, pages 1067–8: #*: One function of '''xanthophobia''' in loggerhead hatchlings may be to reduce the attraction of light sources with a substantial participation of long-wavelength light. #* '''1996''', in ''FMRI Technical Reports'' number 2,<sup >[http://books.google.com/books?id=TtFJAAAAYAAJ ]</sup> Florida Marine Research Institute, page 10: #*: The aversion to yellow light, or '''xanthophobia''', that loggerhead hatchlings show sets them apart from other sea turtle species. #* '''1997''', Kenneth J. Lohmann et al., “Orientation, Navigation, and Natal Beach Homing in Sea Turtles”, chapter 5 of John A. Musick et al. (editors), ''The Biology of Sea Turtles'', CRC Press, {{ISBN|978-0-8493-8422-6}}, [http://books.google.com/books?id=fhm2yGTBiN8C&pg=PA111&dq=xanthophobia page 111]: #*: In contrast, loggerhead hatchlings showed an aversion to light in the green-yellow to yellow region of the spectrum (560 to 600 nm) (Figure 5.2). Although this '''xanthophobia''' (yellow light aversion) is unique to loggerheads, green turtles are less strongly attracted to yellow light than to light of other wavelengths. [[Category:en:Phobias]]

page.title: xictli
page.text: ==Central Nahuatl== ===Alternative forms=== * {{sense|Cholula}} {{l|nhn|xihtli}} ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|nhn|/ˈʃiːktɬi/}} ===Noun=== {{head|nhn|noun}} # {{lb|nhn|Milpa Alta}} [[navel|Navel]] [[Category:Amecameca Central Nahuatl]] [[Category:Milpa Alta Central Nahuatl]] {{c|nhn|Body parts}} ---- ==Classical Nahuatl== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|nci|azc-nah-pro}}, from {{inh|nci|azc-pro|*siku}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|nci|/ˈʃiːkt͡ɬi/}} ===Noun=== {{head|nci|noun|head=xictli}} # [[navel]] #* '''1571''', [[w:Alonso de Molina|Alonso de Molina]], ''[[w:Vocabulario en lengua castellana y mexicana y mexicana y castellana|Vocabulario en lengua castellana y mexicana y mexicana y castellana]]'', f. 159r. col. 1. #*: '''xictli'''. ombligo, o bruxula para tirar derecho. #*: '''xictli'''. navel; or peephole. # [[umbilical cord]] ====Derived terms==== * {{l|nci|axictli}} <!---whirlpool: ātl + xīctli---> ===References=== * “[https://web.archive.org/web/20161203034759/http://whp.uoregon.edu/dictionaries/nahuatl/index.lasso xictli]” in the ''Nahuatl Dictionary'', University of Oregon, 2011.
